thread.title: Dembele insists: 'I didn't get distracted by Chelsea chat'
thread.title_full: Dembele insists: 'I didn't get distracted by Chelsea chat' | Daily Mail Online

author: John Mcgarry For The Scottish Daily Mail
title: Dembele insists: 'I didn't get distracted by Chelsea chat'
text:
Five days after killing off speculation linking him with Chelsea by borrowing a little bit of Hollywood, Moussa Dembele was front and centre again on Sunday, a veritable star with the touch of an assassin.
For all St Johnstone will rightly feel aggrieved about the way the Frenchman was allowed to claim the first goal in a 14-minute hat-trick, only a fool would dispute the quality of his 31-minute contribution.
Fresh from a minor knee injury and a torrent of speculation surrounding a possible move to Stamford Bridge, the 20-year-old - who referenced 'The Wolf of Wall Street' to confirm he was staying at Celtic - put St Johnstone to the sword in quite magnificent style.
Moussa Dembele scored a hat-trick as Celtic comfortably beat St Johnstone on Sunday
Dembele - who was linked with a move to Chelsea - scored a 14-minute hat-trick for Celtic
If this was him playing while not yet fully fit and with other things on his mind, heaven help the rest of the league when he's back up to full speed.
'I feel good about the performance, especially the team aspect - we showed we are strong together and won the game, so we're happy,' Dembele said.
'There has been speculation in the last six months and I don't really listen to what has been said about me.
'I don't really listen to what has been said in the media, I don't really follow it. I just try to do my best when I'm out on the pitch and show everyone the level of how good I am.
Liam Henderson side-foots home the opener for the away side at McDiarmid Park
Celtic recovered after trailing thanks to David Wotherspoon's shot deflecting into the net
'It's easy not to get distracted. I'm a very calm kind of guy and I don't really let this type of thing get in my head. I focus only on enjoying my football at Celtic and I'm very happy to be here.
'It is (flattering) and it motivates me to keep doing well. I'm happy to be here and I hope to be here as long as I can.'
For a brief moment on Tuesday, when pictures of Dembele on a flight to London surfaced on social media, Celtic fans feared the worst.
The Frenchman now admits he was fully aware of the agony they were going through until his colourful Tweet put their minds at rest.
'I was, obviously, because I received a lot of texts but I just went there for a scan on my knee,' he smiled.
'I had a bit of fun with it, it's the best way. There's no need to speak when you see the picture! I know Chelsea's stadium because I was in London for years, but I didn't pass it when I was there - I just went straight for my scan and then back to the airport.'
Dembele fires home the penalty to make it 2-2 and the Frenchman wasn't finished there
The striker reproduced the same 'Wolf of Wall Street' celebration that implied he was staying
There were certainly no signs of any ill effects at McDiarmid Park.
Asked if the penalty conversion was his first touch, Dembele confirmed it was, adding: 'Was there pressure? Yes. I'm a striker so I'm used to it and when I get the chance I'm confident of scoring because it is what I have been doing all my life.'
That's 23 for the season now. With 14 league games to go and as many as four in the Scottish Cup, 30 seems a reasonable expectation if not more.
'My target is in my head and I'm not telling you about it but I'll try to go beyond the target I have,' he added.
Celtic's targets are easier to pin down. Now 27 points clear, the record 29-point margin of victory in the modern era looks well within their grasp.
Eclipsing Paris Saint Germain's 31-point European record is no longer out of the question.
For the former PSG kid, that would have a certain ring to it.
'Yes, but before that we have to win many games and keep performing as well as we can, and then we'll see after that.
The record 29-point margin of victory in the modern era looks well within Celtic's grasp
Scott Sinclair fires home his side's fourth goal as Celtic recorded their 23rd league victory
'I was not aware of the record but we have a great chance to beat it. We have to think game by game and afterwards we will see.'
For Brendan Rodgers, there was never any question that the events of the past week would have any negative influence on his star man.
'It doesn't affect him,' he said. 'He is at a club he wants to be at and you see the difference when you have a No 9. I think he can get to 30 goals. We still have a lot of games and we create a lot of chances.
'That was the objective when I came in to be attack-minded. If he puts the chances away then he should do.'
Reflecting on the win that put his side 27 points clear at the top, Rodgers added: 'I thought our composure in the game was very good.
'We stay calm in pressure moments and I thought our build up play was good.
'Our positioning was good and we could have been more aggressive in our pressing in the first half. But after the break we upped it and were far more dynamic. Our fitness was also a major factor and we wore St Johnstone down because we have them super-fit in the mind.'
